marketNews.title: Danantara Officially Launched
marketNews.content: President Prabowo Subianto officially launched the Danantara Investment Management Agency on Monday, 24 February 2025, following the amendment to the State-Owned Enterprises (SOE) Law that was enacted earlier this month. The agency will be led by Investment and Decarbonisation Minister Rosan Perkasa Roeslani as CEO, with Pandu Sjahrir as CIO and Deputy State-Owned Enterprises Minister Dony Oskaria as COO. Danantara is the second sovereign wealth fund of Indonesia after the Indonesia Investment Authority, operating separately. Bloomberg previously reported that Danantara is President Prabowo’s initiative to mobilise additional funding for strategic projects without inflating the state budget. Dony Oskaria said on Monday that Danantara will manage all SOEs by the end of March 2025. Media reports indicate that seven SOEs will be managed initially: Bank Mandiri (BMRI), Bank Rakyat Indonesia (BBRI), Bank Negara Indonesia (BBNI), Telkom Indonesia (TLKM), PT PLN, PT Pertamina, and Mining Industry Indonesia (MIND ID). Earlier, President Prabowo announced on Thursday, 13 February that Danantara would manage assets exceeding USD 900 billion based on an initial assessment. Bloomberg reported that, according to the combined financial statements of all SOEs at the end of 2023, Indonesia has more than 60 SOEs with total combined assets of USD 638 billion, net profit around USD 20 billion and total dividends to the state of about USD 5 billion. President Prabowo said the government will channel USD 20 billion from budget-saving results to Danantara as initial funding, to finance 20 high-impact national projects across sectors such as downstream nickel, other minerals, artificial intelligence, oil refineries, petrochemical plants, food production, aquaculture and renewable energy. The minimum initial capital was previously planned at IDR 1,000 trillion (approximately USD 60 billion). President Prabowo also promised full transparency, stating the agency can be audited at any time by anyone. Rosan claimed that the agency can be audited by the Audit Board (BPK) and the Corruption Eradication Commission (KPK), though audit is only possible upon a request from the House of Representatives.

marketNews.title: India Considers Raising Vegetable Oil Import Duties, Potential Impact on Indonesian CPO Exports
marketNews.content: The Indian government is likely to raise import duties on vegetable oil to help domestic oilseed farmers after a price slump. The proposed increase would curb demand and reduce imports of crude palm oil, soybean oil and sunflower oil. In September 2024, India raised import duties on several edible oils by 20 percentage points, lifting the CPO import duty to 27.5%. GAPKI chairman Eddy Martono said the tariff hike could pressure Indonesian CPO exports and urged the Indonesian government to lobby India.

marketNews.title: Indonesia’s B40 Biodiesel Requires 14.2 Million Tonnes of CPO in 2025
marketNews.content: The Ministry of Energy and Mineral Resources (ESDM) director Edi Wibowo said on Saturday, 22 February that the implementation of the B40 biodiesel blend in 2025 will require about 14.2 million tonnes of crude palm oil (CPO), roughly 28 % of the projected 2025 CPO production of 50 million tonnes. For comparison, the B35 blend in 2024 needed 12.18 million tonnes, about 24 % of the 2025 production target.

marketNews.title: Malaysia Rules Out Raising Palm-Oil Biodiesel Blend to 20 % in 2025
marketNews.content: Malaysia’s Ministry of Plantation and Commodities announced on Monday, 24 February that it will not raise the biodiesel blend from the current 10 % to 20 % because the required infrastructure would need about USD 146.2 million, which the industry and government are unwilling to fund.

marketNews.title: PPN DTP Incentive for New Home Purchases Extended to End-2025
marketNews.content: The government extended the government-funded value-added tax (PPN DTP) incentive for the purchase of landed houses and apartments until the end of 2025 through Minister of Finance Regulation No. 13/2025. The incentive provides a 100 % rebate for houses priced between IDR 2-5 billion sold between January-June 2025 and a 50 % rebate for the same price range sold between July-December 2025.

marketNews.title: Bank Indonesia Reports 5.9 % M2 Growth in January 2025
marketNews.content: Bank Indonesia reported that broad-money (M2) grew 5.9 % year-on-year in January 2025, up from a 4.8 % increase in December 2024. The growth was driven by loan-only credit growth of 9.6 % YoY in January 2025 (versus 9.7 % YoY in December 2024), net foreign assets rising 2.4 % YoY (versus 0.8 % YoY in December 2024), and net government receivables falling 14.3 % YoY (versus a 17.5 % decline in December 2024).

marketNews.title: President Prabowo Holds First Media Editors Meeting Since June 2023
marketNews.content: President Prabowo Subianto met with dozens of newspaper editors and senior journalists on Saturday, 22 February, marking his first such meeting since June 2023. The discussion covered a range of issues and strategic policies, with the president hoping the meeting would strengthen media-government synergy and nation-building. Political-communication expert Hendri Satrio of Universitas Paramadina noted that poor public communication has been a cause of the president’s media-relations challenges.

marketNews.title: DEN – No Decision Yet on 2027 Fuel-Subsidy Removal
marketNews.content: The National Economic Council (DEN) spokesperson Jodi Mahardi said on Saturday, 22 February that no decision has been made to change the fuel subsidy scheme, and there is no plan to eliminate the subsidised fuel in 2027. The statement came two days after DEN Chairman Luhut Binsar Pandjaitan said he had proposed to President Prabowo to remove the 2027 fuel subsidy and replace it with a direct cash assistance scheme. Energy Minister Bahlil Lahadalia said the blending scheme that combines fuel-subsidy with cash assistance remains the most likely option for 2025, though a start date has not been set.

marketNews.title: Jasa Marga Plans Asset-Recycling of Manado-Bitung Toll Road
marketNews.content: Jasa Marga (JSMR) announced plans to divest its 39.9-km Manado-Bitung (Mabit) toll road because of low traffic and a monthly bank-interest burden of about IDR 200 billion. The company said the road’s low traffic is due to insufficient stakeholder interest in developing the Bitung area, although the road was built to support the Bitung port. Company secretary Ari Wibowo said JSMR remains open to asset-recycling opportunities. JSMR holds 65 % of the toll road through PT Jasamarga Manado Bitung.

tickerNews.title: AUTO Reports 2024 Net Profit Decline – 4.8 % YoY, Beats Consensus
tickerNews.content: Astra Otoparts reported net profit of IDR 505 billion in 4Q24 (-4.8 % YoY, -1.8 % QoQ). The 4Q24 profit made total 2024 net profit of IDR 2 trillion (+10.4 % YoY), equal to 108 % of consensus. Revenue grew 7.5 % YoY to IDR 4.9 trillion (-1.3 % QoQ), raising 2024 revenue to IDR 19 trillion (+2.3 % YoY). The profit decline was driven by an 18 % YoY increase in operating expenses, pushing operating margin down to 5.2 % in 4Q24 (vs 7 % in 4Q23, 6.09 % in 3Q24). Associate-company profit rose 1.4 % YoY to IDR 290 billion (-2.9 % QoQ).

tickerNews.title: EMTK Crossing Trade Transaction Worth 1.72 trillion IDR
tickerNews.content: A crossing-trade transaction of 1.72 trillion IDR (1.72 trillion) involving 4.29 billion EMTK shares, at an average price of 400 IDR per share, was executed on Monday, 24 February 2025. The trade involved also the subsidiary of EMTK, Bukalapak (BUKA) with a total value of 1.34 trillion IDR, comprising 9.74 billion shares at an average price of  138 IDR per share, both below the Friday (21 Feb) closing price of 640 IDR (EMTK) and 151 IDR (BUKA).
